qas.question: Which philosopher from the Muslim world influenced modern philosophy?
In what year was Hayy ibn Yaqdha translated to the Latin language?
What kind of book is Hayy ibn Yaqdha?
What philosophical novel was written in the 16th century?
What was Hayy ibn Yaqdha translated to in the 16th century?

plausible_answers.text: John Locke, Gottfried Leibniz, Melchisédech Thévenot, John Wallis, Christiaan Huygens, George Keith, Robert Barclay, the Quakers, and Samuel Hartlib
empiricism, tabula rasa, nature versus nurture, condition of possibility, materialism, and Molyneux's problem

qas.question: What themes were developed in Tufail's 16th century novel?

context: Yet another influential philosopher who had an influence on modern philosophy was <a0_0><a1_0>Ibn Tufail<a1_0/><a0_0/>. His <a3_0>philosophical novel<a3_0/>, <b4_0>Hayy ibn Yaqdha<b4_0/>, translated into <b5_0>Latin<b5_0/> as Philosophus Autodidactus in <a2_0>1671<a2_0/>, developed the themes of <b7_0>empiricism, tabula rasa, nature versus nurture, condition of possibility, materialism, and Molyneux's problem<b7_0/>. European scholars and writers influenced by this novel include <b6_0>John Locke, Gottfried Leibniz, Melchisédech Thévenot, John Wallis, Christiaan Huygens, George Keith, Robert Barclay, the Quakers, and Samuel Hartlib<b6_0/>.
